results.content: Not worth the price. 5 hr course that repeats itself and gives the most basic explanation of Material-UI. I was expecting more, but at least it gave me a little exposure to a new library. Save your money and read over the documentation
results.content_html: Not worth the price. 5 hr course that repeats itself and gives the most basic explanation of Material-UI. I was expecting more, but at least it gave me a little exposure to a new library. Save your money and read over the documentation

results.content:
The content presented is useful as an introduction to React and Material UI but doesn't get into too much detail, after some time the content gets a little repetitive. 
The instructor is very clear and eloquent so the lectures themselves were easy to understand.
results.content_html:

The instructor is very clear and eloquent so the lectures themselves were easy to understand.

results.content: Very clearly explaining how the tool works.

results.content:

results.content: Redundant material. The same concepts were presented (very clearly) three times. Not that helpful for a real-world application. I prefer the much more comprehensive, "Implement High Fidelity Designs with Material-UI and ReactJS by Zachary Reece.
results.content_html: Redundant material. The same concepts were presented (very clearly) three times. Not that helpful for a real-world application. I prefer the much more comprehensive, "Implement High Fidelity Designs with Material-UI and ReactJS by Zachary Reece.

results.content: Esperava mais detalhes sobre o que é o que dentro do material-ui, nesse curso ela só usa os componentes sem explicar bulhufas o que cada um faz e pq faz. Fraco.
results.content_html: Esperava mais detalhes sobre o que é o que dentro do material-ui, nesse curso ela só usa os componentes sem explicar bulhufas o que cada um faz e pq faz. Fraco.

results.content: The course is great, but there is a huge jump on JS knowledge content from section 4 to 5.  This is not a course for beginners, since the instructor just assumes the students already has JS knowledge (e.g., ..., setState).  It would be helpful if the instructor gives a 5 or 10 second explanation every time a new concept gets introduced and let the student look into the definition/uses case.
results.content_html: The course is great, but there is a huge jump on JS knowledge content from section 4 to 5.
